text: bottle, from Appalachian Vintners fillled, 2/24/15. good aroma, sweet. toasted malt,almond, little grassy. clean golden orange color, good initial head faded quickly, no lace. Sweet flavor. Light body, thim smooth mouthfeel, sweet finish that faded quickly. its nice, very drinkable lager. surprised this held up that well for its age.
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: Bottle. Clear, amber color with a medium, quickly disappearing head. Aroma had subtle notes of brown sugar with just a hint of nuts. Taste was a malty sweet upfront taste with kind of a bland finish. Actually a pretty good beer.

Pours a five plus finger light cream head that fades slowly to a thin layer leaving a good lace. Crystal clear amber color. Good carbonation and medium bodied. Sweet grassy nose and taste is smooth, some malty sweetness, good session lager. 22oz bottle filled Feb 2015, gift from North Carolina.

Clear golden with a fairly large white head. Aroma is slight wheat and hay. Flavor is very light with just a hint of sweetness in the finish. Refreshing.

Wife: 3.5

Bomber from Bruisin Ales, 4/10/15. Clear dark golden, almost orange, thin fizzy tan head, poor retention. Aroma of toasted malt, spicy hops. The taste is caramel and toasted malt, some graininess, mild stone fruits, grassy, herbal hops. Medium bodied, high carbonation, well balanced. Solid.

22oz bottle. Amber color. Lagered aroma. Smells of toasted malts. Smooth taste. Clean, easy drinking. Toasted grains, fruity esters. creamy texture. 
(4356)

Pours clear golden with a minimal eggshell head. Aroma is not strong, but has nice fruity and malty notes. Crisp flavor surprises with its strength, and adds a snip or two of hops to e mix. Mouthfeel has good body and a firm, persistent fizz. I love Mozarts music! Maybe I should be listening to one of his symphonies right now.

650 ml. filled 02/24/15. Pours clear orange-amber with a lasting island of creamy foam on top. Aroma is dark bread, earthy honeycomb and touches of citrus and spicy dry grass. Tastes of honey, lightly tart apple, toast and a finish of hay, mild lemon and graham cracker. Light-medium body is too fizzy but has a delicate balance.

Draft. This is a fantastic lager. Damn, so happy to have this locally. Pours a translucent amber with a light white head that fades fast. Nose is light caramel, biscuit malts, grass, hay, really awesome. Flavor follows suit. Highland is really killing it with the lagers lately. This and the Belmont Pilsner might be my too favorite beers from Highland. Thanks for the recc. De-rock!

Bomber. Beautiful golden color with rising bubbles and a one-finger white head. The aroma is malty and grainy, lots of bread and mild grassy hops. The flavor has a bready malt base with a touch of caramel, but without the sweetness. Some mild hop bitterness on the finish. Medium body with a fairly average mouthfeel, but crisp and dry. Pretty nice little wiener lager, I must say.

Pours into the glass a walnut-orange with a wispy head that fully diminishes, leaving trace suds to the fringes. The nose is of malts and light sourdough. Flavors are not too heavy, perfect for a session ale, with caramel, light biscuit and cereal notes, tannins, and finishing with a curt, balancing hop that closes the pull nicely. Medium-bodied, semi-active on the palate with a easy-drinking, light mouthfeel. A perfect accompaniment for Easter dinner!

Clean tawny amber pour with two fingers of tight off-white head. Nice aroma with a light bready sweetness, grassy hops, toasted grain, and hay. Mellow and easy to drink with a nice and round bready malt profile that shows a light caramel sweetness on the finish. A bright and grassy hop character follows with a medium light body.
Clear orange, thin head. Smells like fresh bread and black pepper, Taste is toashty, peppery, and some grassy notes. Nice, clean finish. Simple and tasty.
